data.text: ek post

Any of you start Bicycle touring at a older age? I am just starting and only doing three or four day trips at a time. I am 46 years old. I plan on doing much longer touring when I retire. I will be 55 at that time.
Many people do their first tour after they‚Äôve retired, often in their 60s. Then they wish they hadn‚Äôt waited so long!
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: I toured,short tours, when I was younger, long distance, started in my 40's
data.author: Paul Rodriguez

data.text: Took my second ‚Äúovernight‚Äù at 58, exactly 40 years after my first (reliving a trip done with friends after HS graduation). I went on one more overnight before doing the Pacific Coast Highway at 59. And Route 66 started the day after my 60th, finishing 52 days later. The bike will be ready for you whenever you‚Äôre ready.
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: Started touring solo in New Zealand and Australia age 42. Did long tour with my husband age 49, age 56, age 65-67 (onn this tour, signed up for Social Security from Central Asia) and last summer cycled coast to coast and down east coast to Boston 4927 miles, and while on the tour celebrated 71st birthday at Niagara Falls. This past summer did an 8 day tour in our home state of Idaho.
data.author: Rachel Hugens

data.text: I started touring again at 67 when I retired, have done 4 tours now
data.author: Larry Matthews

data.text: 64 and going strong... JUST DO IT! and ENJOY :-)
data.author: Joseph Fenner

data.text: Retired and started seriously riding at age 68. Rode 5300 miles last year.
data.author: Steve Dintaman

data.text: I learned to ride a bike when I was 40. Did my first tour two years later.
data.author: TC Hal√ªk Okur

data.text: I‚Äôve been doing short tours since I turned 70, 5 years ago.
data.author: Fritz Kucklick

data.text: Much too young to think about
data.author: Maximilian Sichart

data.text: Did my first self supported tour at 62. Still enjoying it at 74.
data.author: Paul Lieberman

data.text: I started bike-packing at 64 years young. So far, two to four-day tours.
data.author: Stuart Doyle

data.text: Started at age 50, still going strong today at 68.
data.author: R Bruce W Laubach

data.text: Started at 50
data.author: Jeff Stone

data.text: Youngster!
data.author: Phil Dicken

data.text: 60, doing week or two, max three weeks trips, still working...
data.author: Mojca Visner

data.text: Yes started at 52 I‚Äôm now 60. My last trip pre-Covid was 10 months long!
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: 50 and just getting started. 13 miles on a round trip consistently so far. I'm sure I can go farther but I some things to work on first
data.author: Laurence Nixon

data.text: First long trip at 49! 2.5 years RTW!!
data.author: Roger Sims

data.text: 46, you're only a kid!!
data.author: Nick Hanson

data.text: I started touring at 60 and am now 73. Have done the Northern Tier, then half the Atlantic Coat, and the Trans Am at 70!! Never too old!
data.author: Anne Powell Cowan

data.text: Most tourists are either old and mostly-retired or young. I did the TransAm, solo, at the age of 57.
data.author: Shaun Ivory

data.text: I did it at 56, but not solo. My last trip was 1000 miles this summer at 67. Thing is I started this in my mid-twenties. and I want to keep it going as long as I can. I would love to do the TransAm again at 70 and take twice as long to do it.
data.author: James Schoettgen

data.text: I feel like a middle age minority at 37. Mind you I've been doing this forever...
data.author: Derek Poshtar

data.text: 60 when I started
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: I did supported week long tours while I was working. After I retired I rode supported Seattle to Boston on my road bike at 64. At 68 I rode self-supported the Tour Divide Banff to Antelope Wells. You got this. You‚Äôll have a great time.
data.author: Cher Barron

data.text: You call 55 old? I'm gonna be 70 next May and plan to celebrate with a bike tour on the GAP & C&O Canal. Hope to do the Sunflower Tour with Bike Florida too. Also plan to sneak in some scuba diving. Don‚Äôt die until you‚Äôre dead!
data.author: Beverly Payton

data.text: Hi I am 71 love bike backing keep an going üëç
data.author: Jacob Vandermark

data.text: I‚Äôm 71 and this year it‚Äôs hard, (might be long term COVID fatigue), but was doing Central America and Mexico regularly at 65. Enjoy it as best you can as long as you can baby
data.author: Dave Renfrow

data.text: My first long tour was the ACA Northern Tier, over 4000 miles, solo, at age 65. Planning a 2-3 month solo tour in Europe next summer
data.author: Mary Ann Anderson

data.text: 62üö¥
data.author: David Allan

data.text: 46 is the new 26
data.author: Drew Molnar

data.text: 39 for me
data.author: Brandy Howe

data.text: I was in my 40s when I started.
data.author: Thomas Batty

data.text: It‚Äôs like planting trees. The best time to plant is 2 years ago, the next best time is now!
data.author: Jeff Kalmus

data.text: I started 7 years ago..... I'm now 63 and heading out in 2023 Canada to Ushaia
data.author: Brian Sculac

data.text: Hey kiddo
data.author: Marcus Wisdorf

data.text: My second tour, after a 25 year hiatus, was at 60. Now 70 and finishing up London to Prague. Don't sweat it!
data.author: Dave Morgan

data.text: Good for you! I plan to retire soon at 65 and am hoping to do longer tours, too.
data.author: Carlos Alcala

data.text: Retired at 53. Got started into touring. Juggling money and commitments can make touring challenging. I tour locally & regionally days/week at a time. Plenty to see. Many stealthy places. Peanut butter & jelly sandwiches last a long time. Rice, bkfst bars etc...
data.author: Preston Paige Piper

data.text: Started touring this year at 68
data.author: Steve Mullin

data.text: Started bike commuting to work in my mid 30's. Planning for my first trip now that I'm in my mid 40's. As long as you have a good bike fit, it should be fine because cycling is relatively low impact.
data.author: Brian Neal

data.text: I did my first trip in my late 30s. I rode across the US and parts of Ontario. My ex wife is from China and I started learning Russian almost 15 years ago so I've been able to travel across Russia and China too.
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: First tour age 60, about 15,000 miles of touring in 13 years.
data.author: Don Millikin

data.text: Did first little one this year. I‚Äôm 64 my wife 62.
data.author: Kevin Allen

data.text: I started four years ago at the age of 55. Now 59 and loving touring.
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text: You're only a child in touring terms. I did my first major solo unsupported trip (from San Francisco to Boston) when I was 58 - and I wasn't old then!
data.author: Mick Dolan

data.text: Just turned 60 and did my first 3 day trip‚Ä¶.
data.author: Terri White

data.text: I have met an 81 year old man while at Yellowstone nat'l park who was crossing America on a bicycle.
data.author: Vladimir Tolskiy

data.text: I toured a bit in my 20s but then didn't again till my kids were grown and I was retired. I have done much more touring as a 60+ year old than as a youngster. Its always good.
data.author: Peggy Seidel

data.text: My wife and I did our first self supported bike tour at the age of 50. 900+ miles over 6 weeks in France, Switzerland, and Germany. Some things that worked for us: we rode 5 of 7 days on average, we didn't have a firm schedule so objectives for the day were flexible, started slow and built speed/endurance over the first two weeks, routes stayed near rivers/canals for the first three weeks, often stopped mid-day for a nap in the shade.
data.author: Tom Moritz

data.text: Starting on my first tour on Monday at 63 years old. Been road riding for quite some time but now set to travel 400km in four days in the South West of France. Wish me luck! ü§ì
data.author: Andy Walter

data.text: I started early spring the year I turned 55 by riding 12 miles every other day. Slowly increased the daily milage and was riding 60 plus days within a few months. Finished that year with just short of 4000 miles. Three years later I rode across the United States 2900 miles coast to coast on a fully supported tour. The following year I rode 4300 miles coast to coast self contained on a longer, more mountainous route. I think I came in at about 8000 miles total that year. It's a fun sport and from what I can see most people who are really into it are early to mid 60's. I have many cycling friends in their 70's and one buddy who is 88.
data.author: Jim Hilly

data.text: I learned to swim front-crawl at your age and I started camping, bikepacking and mountain biking now (over 50). I will continue to push the limits as long as possible.
data.author: Jenny Sun

data.text: Started when I was 55 right after cancer surgery and never looked back.
data.author: John Boyle

data.text: You will be 55 when you retire? Respect.
data.author: Tobi We

data.text: Do what YOU want to do, there are no limits really. We have crossed France (2019) and just returned from several weeks in Alsace-plus several other multi-day tours. At 67 and 78 we plan routes carefully and do hotels vs camp but touring is a major wonderful thing in our lives!
data.author: Sheree Sonfield

data.text: 46 isn‚Äôt old
data.author: Mark Skarpohl

data.text: My first ride longer than a week, I was 59.
data.author: Henri Cervantes

data.text: I'm 54 and just started a couple of years ago. I rode across Germany last summer, did the C&O and GAP trails last October with my friend who was 69 at the time and I'm just finishing up a tour from Croatia to Italy right now. I've been really encouraged by the "older" people in our group doing incredible trips.
data.author: Lisa Gennaci Glas

data.text: If you bicycle daily ‚Ä¶.: Going long distance is a piece of cake‚Ä¶..
data.author: David O'Neill

data.text: Do not wait. The world and you might be gone.
data.author: Shoshana Mueller

data.text: I did my Oregon to Massachusetts ride at 70.
data.author: Dennis Blanchard

data.text: Started at 56
data.author: Larry LaFavor

data.text: Leave home when you retire at 55 and return 10 years later at 65
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: I'm 65 and just soloed from Alaska back to California but I've been doing it for 50 years
data.author: Edward Gregory

data.text: I did my first tour at 55, cross country on the Southern Tier. It was a 34 day / 3100 mile ride. I‚Äôve been across 4 times now and most of the Great Divide.
data.author: Rob Robertson

data.text: 67 and love it
data.author: JoAnn Kopke

data.text: I did my first this year at 49
data.author: James Fenn

data.text: I did my first tour just before I turned 40 (GAP/C&O) and have tried to do at least a 150 mile ride every year since. I'll be 45 for the 4th year in a row in November!
data.author: Carl Fisher

data.text: You think 46 is "older"? üòÇ
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: I rode self supported from the source of the Mississippi River in northern Minnesota to its mouth in the Gulf of Mexico ( Venice, Louisiana) at the age of 70. (2,354 miles)
data.author: Gary Schmidt

data.text: I started in my mid sixties- enjoy
data.author: Werner Mathiuet

data.text: You're not an older age. Off you go üòÄ
data.author: Nathan Stewart

data.text: Did my first major tour at 69 I've done some great rides since, doing the Natchez Trace next month at 75, age is just a figure üëå üö≤üö≤ü•≥ü•≥üö≤üö≤
data.author: John Edwards

data.text: 59 Just cycled from Zurich to Rotterdam
data.author: Steve Gambrell

data.text: I rode the Trans America route in 6 weeks when I was fifty... 46 isn't very old.
data.author: Kerry Palmer

data.text: It's never too old to start anything except for s** üòâü§£
data.author: Rita Wong

data.text: Started touring at age 59. Retired working at age 66, and went 9250 miles solo around the US in 9-1/2 months. Safe travels, and have fun!üö≤üíï
data.author: Judith Stoffer

data.text: 55 is older age? No. You have many good years to ride. We went across the U S at age 60:and 64, planning our next ride.
data.author: Michael Voorhorst

data.text: Since when did 46 become an "older age?" LOL! I'm in my 70s and still doing it just fine.
data.author: Lee Carruthers

data.text: This is about the happiest bunch of posts anyone could read. Bravo to all!!!!
data.author: Dave Renfrow

data.text: I started in my 60's. I'm almost 71. I've done all of Western Europe a couple of times. Some in the US and Thailand and a lot in Mexico (where I live) and Central America. I'm hoping for Vietnam in a couple of months. You've a long way to go before you get old.
data.author: Daniel Ellsworth

data.text: We started bicycle touring in our late 50's. Our first long trip was the Katy Trail. Since then we have done 2 coast to coasts plus many other great rides.
data.author: Chrysa Niewald

data.text: At 58 I took my bike from Australia to New Zealand and spent 6 weeks but 3 weeks were with friends also from Australia. Back to Australia for family then left for England on the1st Jun do the west to east coast, then time with Aussie friend who had family there and then onto Wales for a few weeks and then on to Ireland meet some people from Australia and court up with them again a few times. Off to Europe and did some house sitting in France, spent pretty well 3 months and solo and tenting most of it. It was awesome but slowly the weather was getting colder and my solo self had sort of run out. Companionship was pretty well missing by the end. Back to England for 4 weeks then off with my sister to Morocco, Portugal and back to France, left sis in Switzerland snow skiing while I headed back to England and return to Australia. Back to Australia and purchased a caravan as my 4x4 was in Newcastle and waited for sis to come and then we set off to drive back to Darwin. Trip of a life time told the kids I was taking a gap year. Did 2,395 + klm and camped alot of the time. That was 2018 what a year and I still have to pinch myself every day. 62 now and still would love to do it all again, still solo so probably will be doing it solo again. Italy is the dream, America and Canada long haul from Australia but it still is a plan one day. Onon üö≤üö¥‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüö≤ don't waste time just live life it can be to short lost my Brother this year 64 and he only retired at 60 and spent those 4 years fitting Brain Turmor. So go for it.
data.author: Deborah Rugg

data.text: Yeah, I think you are taking the piss here! Nothing to see here.
data.author: Norman White

data.text: I started at 50 üòäüòÇ
data.author: Jude Willett

data.text: Lol. Too old. Might as well sell your bike and gear.
data.author: Jim Ryan

data.text: Yep. that is what I did. Started cycling at 50, short bikepacking trips at 53 and retired at 55. Now 57. Last few years I'm completing multiple multi-week trips each year. (GAP/C&O, Katy Trail, Cowboy Trail, and many others) Great thing about retirement is that you have time to train and learn how to recover more effectively. I continue to get stronger each year - trips now average 80 miles per day, and range up to 100 miles in a day. For me it works. It all depends on your goals. It is a good life if you can pull it off. Good luck!
data.author: Jim Sober

data.text: 59 years young. Been at it for 14? Years. Usually 3-5 day rolls around New England. Some overnights too.
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck

data.text: 46 sounds so very young to me, now.... You are not "older" you are "younger" - it's all a matter of perspective.
data.author: Ken Bradford

data.text: Man, you are a teenager!
data.author: Garry James

data.text: I‚Äôm 49 and planning at 2 month European trip of 3,500km
data.author: Scott Malpass

data.text: i started at the age of 61 riding from germany to the northcape and back through russia and the baltics ‚Äì 7,100 km/90 days. at 66 i cycled the silkroad to singapore ‚Äì 14,000 km/320 days. still riding now at 76, next year vienna-oman, some 8,000 km/6 months. all self-supported, no electric engines. hence, you‚Äôre still very young and ready for many long-haul cycling tours. just go for it! üëç
data.author: Herbert F. W. Born

data.text: Started when I was abou 55. Wished I‚Äôd done it years earlier. Hasn‚Äôt stopped me enjoying it though.
data.author: Steve Ormes

data.text: I did my first when I was about 38 or 39. Last, number c.87 in 2017. Haven't gone since though I'm not ruling it out. It's kind of addictive. I used to do average of 70m/d when I started. It's not about the miles, though but about the enjoyment, talking to people, looking at curiosities and so on. I've cycled in Ireland (I live here), extensively in Britain, France, Spain, Portugal, extensively in Germany, Italy, Andorra, Austria, Corsica, Sardinia, Greece, once, Canada once, Switzerland, briefly, Denmark.
data.author: Gear√≥id √ì Laoi

data.text: Did my first self supported tour at 55 - five weeks in Iran crossing over from Dogubayuzit in Turkey. Planning my next one through the " 'stans" back into Iran - will make it a lot longer next time. Enjoy your touring
data.author: Richard Gould

data.text: 59.5 - left my house in Ontario Canada two days ago - destination is as far as we get over ten weeks - hopefully San Diego CA - around 4,800 Km‚Äôs
data.author: Snoopy Vmaris

data.text: I did the Southern Tier solo, unsupported, starting in San Diego arriving in St. Augustine for my 64th birthday. ‚úÖ Bucket List.
data.author: Lee Wenzler

data.text: 64 and touring more!
data.author: Brett T Roncelli

data.text: I biked 150 miles in one day for my 55th birthday. You'll be fine...just start pedaling!
data.author: Mike Schlacter

data.text: We toured in our 40s, then started in again in our late 60s, after semi-retirement. In our late 70s now, we tour in a van and ride mostly trails, out-and-back choice segments. Our last multi-day self-supported tour, three weeks, was to celebrate the stoker's 70th, two years after my bypass surgery.
data.author: Larye Parkins

data.text: I started touring (multi day trips) at age 49. Longer yours soon thereafter. My mega tour was at age 53 - 3 months, more than 2200 miles. One of the highlights of my entire life.
data.author: David Yelenchic

data.text: First tour was at 47. First time I rode a bike I was 40. Rode a borrowed bike for a few kilometers. Didn‚Äôt ride again until we picked up our bikes in Spain and toured Europe for six months.
data.author: Grant Griffin

data.text: That‚Äôs hardly ‚Äòold‚Äô.
data.author: Pat Anunda Guinane

data.text: Did world Tour at 41 for 2 years. Did many trip in Europe, USA, Canada. Now going to tour South Korea at 53 years old. Juste enjoy it at every age. Tailwind to you.
data.author: Louis-Philippe Gendron

data.text: I just turned 75 and I still enjoy touring. At 46 you are still a kid. LOl. You still have many years of touring ahead of you. Enjoy yourself, Amigo!
data.author: John Robert Michael

data.text: I think I was about your age when I did my first. Started with a 3 day loop in coastal North Carolina over the Xmas holidays. The next Memorial Day I decided to tackle the mountains, doing a 4 day loop in the Appalachians of NC and VA. I was hooked by then. Cancer sidetracked me for awhile, but after recovering from my second major surgery related to that, I was determined to do a long trip. Got a proper tourer and flew to Europe for a 6 week trip. That was at 50 and I figured now or never. I beat the odds with my cancer, and just celebrated 54 on a second long trip across Europe this summer.
data.author: Rodney Boles

data.text: You are super young!! Just get out there as much as you want to.
data.author: Ginnis McGinnis

data.text: that's not an older age
data.author: Link Lindquist

data.text: I also started in my 60's.
data.author: P Ann Akif

data.text: My first multi-day tour (6 days) I was 55. I will tour until my body gives out. It‚Äôs just a number.
data.author: Lonnie N. Dearth

data.text: I did my first 4 tours at age 56 with my high school age daughter; 377 miles each summer from Fairbanks to Anchorage, Alaska. When I retired at 60 I did the southern tier. I‚Äôve done 8 long distance rides since, including one across China. I‚Äôm going to be 70 this year and looking forward to riding Route 66 from Chicago to Phoenix in October. Riding a bike keeps you young at almost any age!
data.author: Donald Hoshaw

data.text: old? 46? 55?? that's not old! :)
data.author: Chuck Hood

data.text: 46 is an older age? WTH?
data.author: Brent Futrell

data.text: No. I was your age when I started. I imagine I will still be doing it when I am old though, but I try to focus on the now.
data.author: Tom Dull

data.text: I started my first tour when I was 50, 7 cross countries, included a perimeter tour on my last tour I turned 70 years old. I am now 78 and mountain bike regularly. I am currently in Moab watching it rain. If you rest you rust so don't quit. Next stop Kansas.
data.author: George Rickard

data.text: I completed my solo tour from Leduc, Alberta Canada to Charlottetown PEI, Canada in August 2022 which was 5470 km in total over about 2.5 months. I am 58. It wasn't easy but it was amazing, rewarding and I learned so much about my country and myself. I'm planning my second for the summer of 2023. You are never too old . . .
data.author: Jamie Simmons

data.text: We were in our 60s when we started. Unfortunately, my husband has has a series of health problems, though, so our bike touring days are pretty much over. We usually toured on bike trails (e.g., the GAP, Le Petit Temis in Quebec‚Ä¶
data.author: Phyllis A. Stone

data.text: I did my first 70 days trip at 55
data.author: Enrico Chierici
